comment._content: ObStreetview

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The Clock House was build around 1855, by Sir Denham Orlando Jephson. He was an amateur architect who is said to have designed this house after he had returned from an alpine holiday. The Clock was brought from the tower of the Old Mallow Castle. The bell was cast at Millerd Street, Cork. The bell tower became dangerous and was removed c1970, but was restored in 1995.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Excellent, thank you! Sad to see it empty and "To Let". Added to our Flickr map, and now I'm wondering if the street in the foreground was called "Thomas Davis Street" at the time this photo was taken? Oh, if only some kind person could find it in their heart to check the OSI Historic maps, sigh!  ;)

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: It is simply called Davis Street maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,556114,598341,7,9

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: It was offically renamed 'Thomas Davis Street' in 1906 - before that I think it was 'Main Street'.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Census of 1901 gives it as Main Street, 1911 says Davis Street.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The 1911 census lists William Fitzpatrick living in a public house at 82 Davis Street, which I believe is the pub on the left, although it lists his occupation as "Estate Agents Clerk and Presscarrysvt" according to the transcription, which I think actually means Press Correspondent. His wife does not list an occupation, but it seems quite likely that that is her, Ellen Fitzpatrick, at her door in the apron.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You're dead right about the Fitzpatrick's. I did a bit of house by house 1911census work on Davis Street: 81: Cornelius O'Donovan, Coach Builder and Ironmonger & wife Bride 82: William Fitzpatrick, Estate Agents Clerk and Press Correspondent? & wife Ellen 83: Denis Cremin, Publican & wife Margaret 84: Patrick Healy, Publican 86: John Cronin, Vintner & wife Kate Coach Builder and Ironmonger at no. 81 ties in with "Factory". Odd that Fitzpatrick at no. 82 doesn't mention Publican or Vintner as it's so obviously a pub. The sign for Cremin's Restaurant ties in with Denis Cremin the publican at no. 83.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Just to add to the confusion, the 1911 phone directory still refers to Main Street.
